title: Here’s what Healey put up in her Super Bowl bet with Washington state governor
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey wagered Dunkin' coffee and Legal Sea Foods items in a Super Bowl bet with Washington Gov. Bob Ferguson.
If the Seahawks lose, Ferguson promised to send shellfish and coffee to Healey, following their Super Bowl LX matchup.
Healey will attend Super Bowl LX in Santa Clara, California, promoting Massachusetts' economy and tourism during a work trip.

title: Woman convicted of fraud after living under a stolen identity for more than 20 years
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Lina Maria Orovio-Hernandez was convicted of identity theft and fraud after using a stolen identity for over 20 years.
She illegally collected $400,000 in benefits, including $260,000 in Section 8 and $101,000 in Social Security payments.
Orovio-Hernandez faces deportation after serving a potential prison sentence for multiple identity theft-related offenses.

title: Celtics rally from 22 down in Vucevic’s debut to beat Heat: 6 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Celtics overcame a 22-point deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 98-96 at TD Garden.
Nikola Vucevic made his Celtics debut, contributing 11 points and 12 rebounds off the bench.
Payton Pritchard's 19-point performance was key to Celtics' second-half comeback against the Heat.

title: Tom Brady shows support for Patriots ahead of Super Bowl LX after saying he ‘doesn’t have a dog in the fight’
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Tom Brady expresses support for Patriots owner Robert Kraft ahead of Super Bowl LX, despite earlier neutrality.
Brady faced backlash for not openly supporting the Patriots; current players criticized his stance.
Brady's historical ties to the Patriots include six Super Bowl titles and a statue at Gillette Stadium.

title: Former Colts Pro Bowl center thinks Drake Maye should have won NFL MVP over Matthew Stafford
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Jeff Saturday argued Patriots' QB Drake Maye deserved the 2026 NFL MVP over Rams' Matthew Stafford.
Matthew Stafford won 2026 NFL MVP, beating Drake Maye by six points; Maye excelled in dual-threat statistics.
Mina Kimes voted for Maye, highlighting his superior QBR and efficiency compared to Stafford's traditional metrics.

title: 5 X-factors for Patriots, Seahawks in Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Sam Darnold's performance against the Patriots' blitz-heavy defense is crucial, given his high playoff success but regular-season struggles under pressure.
Drake Maye's scrambling ability could exploit the Seahawks' weak defense against quarterback rushes, crucial for the Patriots' game strategy.
Patriots' linebacker Robert Spillane's ankle injury could impact their run defense against Seahawks' running back Kenneth Walker's playoff success.

title: Patriots get good Drake Maye news on final injury report, but 2 captains are listed as questionable
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots' quarterback Drake Maye has no injury designation and is expected to play in Sunday's Super Bowl.
Linebackers Harold Landry and Robert Spillane are listed as questionable for the Patriots due to knee and ankle injuries.
Patriots' Joshua Farmer and Seahawks' Robbie Ouzts are also questionable for the upcoming Super Bowl matchup.

title: 5 must-watch movies & TV shows streaming right now
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'Hell or High Water' (2016), a contemporary Western by Taylor Sheridan, is streaming on Netflix.
'Splitsville' (2025), a romantic comedy featuring Kyle Marvin and Dakota Johnson, is available on Hulu.
The 2026 Winter Olympics are streaming on Peacock with highlights on NBC's tape-delayed coverage.

title: ‘We all we got, we all we need’: How Stefon Diggs’s  voice sparked a New England rallying cry
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Stefon Diggs's phrase 'we all we got, we all we need' has become a rallying cry for the New England Patriots.
The phrase originated during the Patriots' Week 5 win against the Buffalo Bills, sparking a dramatic season turnaround.
Diggs faces assault charges, but remains a key leader as the Patriots prepare for Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks.

title: She’s running her first-ever marathon to raise money for Mass. General Hospital
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Armanda Demeris from North Attleboro is running her first marathon in the 2026 Boston Marathon.
She aims to raise funds for Massachusetts General Hospital, supporting emergency response, cancer care, and veteran programs.
Her motivations include personal connections to MGH's emergency services, cancer research, and the Home Base veteran program.
